HIE-cyfayCU4qxCF495LgA.text: Very cute and quirky cafe, and is apparently associated with the magazine of the same name. The coffee here is really good, personally on par with Monmouth here. The americano was clean and not too acidic. Once you incorporate the design of the cafe and all the fancy packaging, I would probably rate Monocle as one of the best in the city.Seating is a bit cramped and limited, and they don't have wifi (!!!)

ioFGufN16NtP8BxApsNTig.text: Nice coffee and great for a lazy Sunday go-to. Small so can be difficult to get seating but has been designed well. Haven't had a meal there but great pastries. Super helpful staff.

Y3-Vta8bxJ2jW3xRLwwKlg.text: This place is really, really cute. Coffee is solid, if a bit on the expensive side (£3 for a flat white).The room beyond the bar on the ground floor is decorated like somebody's living room. There's a couch, a few seats along the walls, and a big coffee table in the centre. There's also a nice big flatscreen TV mounted in the corner, which is great for people like me who want a little ambient noise while working.The biggest drawback though is the lack of wifi. I don't know if they have plans to install wifi in the future.Cool bathroom with hi-tech Japanese toilet though!

v1w3NtNolQaHwlhIAeQz6A.text: Their Japanese breakfast is cute, healthy and filling and their coffee is great. The hip crowd makes it too crowded and a bit slow, but still worth it.

sX0aB5DWYnxzlDoQ9q9-3g.text: The place looks great, really chic and considered. I love the colour scheme they have and the staff were very helpful and friendly. The green tea chiffon cake was uh-mazing, the lightest fluffiest thing I have ever eaten. I would go back just for this.Maybe I'm being pernickety, but there are a few small things that marred the experience somewhat. The quiet back room seems to have too many sofas for the space, and fairly close proximity and enclosing walls means you can't help but eavesdrop on other people's conversations. That's probably just me being a serial eavesdropper but at least make it difficult for us, jeez. Another small thing, there's no where to put your teabags, so I ended up dumping it in a (very beautiful) glass rather let my tea steep forever. The weirdest thing was the combination of Bloomberg rolling news and Monocle radio. Have one or the other, rather than a weird overlay of chirpy indie music and depressing international news. It added a mildly farcical cacophonous air to a place that would otherwise be relaxing and quiet.

oQsXiHpHpHqjgyH2iLuSFw.text: Reallyyy good food and fun place to sit and read or work,:

EZ70Lxe3WpDVDDOOyNfNBQ.text: Finally a good coffee! £3 for Allpress beans from New Zealand, two shots by default, milk steamed to delicious creaminess (and not too bloody hot like everywhere else), just lovely. Forgot the chocolate on my cappuccino but still 5 stars since I don't really care about that and it was take away. Hopefully the next ones are as good!

sDzNg4xa13mUtfAWs3EDRA.text: Worth a trip to London all on its own. Great coffee (I think they put some cardamom in it).

tIydI6vNAUeSpTm49u34-A.text: Cool vibe. Great place to get a decent coffee and meet people. I do my casual business meetings here. Quiet loungy elegance.

CQaDBl_Zzx8C0F3j3z1vXg.text: So now we might be paying £3 for a cup of coffee... at least it's a good one. A damn good one, but I really just can't keep up with London inflation...

-JB3EyRyDJp9B13H4vDZ8w.text: How much one can really judge a cafe from taking a take away.. Well, my experience was - great coffee, super friendly service & super nice space...

KHP573YFtiOwoa6p7SjA1w.text: Dropped by this place on one my last morning's in London. Enjoyed a great espresso with some pastries in a nice cozy modern interior. Ended up picking up a copy of the Monocle Guide To Better Living book as a gift on my way out as well.

FKgrjdAWpEDxj088RIllkQ.text: I can see what the hype is about and honestly it is there! Set on a hybrid of cool, hip, and posh, Monocle cafe is an exuberance of the magazine, very characteristic, very genuine. Staff is simply amazing, friendly, helpful, flexible and cool. The reason I gave it three stars is because the seating plan is extremely uncomfortable, makes you feel like you better eat up and leave. There is no WiFi for customers which seems a bit odd for the style of monocle which is to me all about global identities and style. Perhaps the cafe is too popular amongst residents and this is the only way they have found to contend with cafe trodders who otherwise stick around for hours with their laptops. Who knows? Food is okay. Simple cafe fare. Rather limited but decent options. Would I go back? Perhaps if I'm passing through the neighborhood, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.

M09mI7BCvqbsNNi9MeRGQw.text: Food was really good almost like real one. But food was kinda small lol Definitely good food.

ra5BsY3A2zhMtRHdf7OU1w.text: Lovely little Japanese cafe. Actually, you know what I don't know what it actually is!! They seem to have travel journals & magazine as well as serving great coffee & Japanese food as well as Scandinavian brekkie!!! The katsu prawn sandwich is the most delicious underwhelming sandwich I've ever had!! My mum took me to this little place as shes obsessed, and rightly so, with their coffees. I was hungry so tried that one, half convinced to be honest. But it was amaziiiing! looks simple but tasty extraordinary!!

2pQ6yUTapW3WfO9T8NSPXw.text: Monocle coffee is a London standard. A friend told me it's not about the coffee or the magazine. It's about the lifestyle.That's says it.

3fH7MjVfj7ke54hq9glEaw.text: Wow wow wow it's a great late I ever had.. It's matcha latte ( green tea latte ) unique latte the taste was delicious .. Cinnamon Buns was Yuumy .. The store was decorated in a nice way they have a small rest room was really cute ..staff are friendly all in all guys you should visit them

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom

xi_LrnsPSWLSCQtj6HAiKw.text: How cool is it that your favorite magazine has it's own stores and cafes? I love how Monocle designed this little and very cute café right on the cozy Chiltern Street.A large variety of different coffees and teas are available, while the menu is very international. An assortment of pastries are also available. Coffee here is good, you can read the magazine for free or buy their bargain: The newest magazine and a cup of coffee at only 6 GBP.I love the design. Light, little and very cozy. Everything with a japanese twist of course.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom

yX_FsfxgZmO9ZqEKVnELdQ.text: One of the cutest cafes in London. Great vibe, and great coffee especially for fans of the brand in general. Best to visit during the week when it's quieter, as its small size really limits how many people can enjoy a trip there. Main downfall has to be the lack of WiFi, and the charge for card payments (for an upscale business it's really quite tacky).

MwI4wYJYF8mfTuO1d1Xk3Q.text: I really like this place. The coffee is good but more so than most it has a very unique character about it because of its style and decor. Very minimal and light. Think Japan meets Scandinavia.I had a great winter mulled wine there but they also do (pricey) food options. If anything get the cake to go with your drink. Just opposite chiltern firehouse which is cool, and on a very nice, almost quintessential English street.

Ozklb1WFX77WNshmCIPPRA.text: Very nice and quirky cafe, it might look a bit crammed but the design & ambiance make it look quite cozy. They have a lovely sofa room, couple of tables downstairs & outside so you can pick what bests suits your visit.They do an amazing coffee but a bit on the pricey side (£3 for flat white, £3,5 mocha). They also get extra brownie points since i saw the barista discarding a great looking  americano & making an excellent looking americano instead before serving it.Their sandwiches & pastries are delicious! But the rest of the food options even though they are nice they are a bit small, which is ok for breakfast but not so great if you are going for lunch. It is worth noting that they from the few shops which serve karma cola if you want a decent soft drink.Finally, they don't have wifi which is pretty normal considering that they don't have that many seats.

3cMltb-NruxqAkrmKKfG4Q.text: Despite being situated just off Marylebone high street, Monocle cafe lacks any pretension you may expect for the area.  The coffee is above decent and the presentation on little airplane style trays, which really they could do without, is kind of sweet. Speaking of sweet, if you are in the market for a mind-blowing chelsea bun, despite this being a Japanese themed cafe, they are pretty brilliant here.

zCPL7GqXtcIRswga1dYdgQ.text: Delightful coffee bar and restaurant. Had a fantastic coffee and an avocado toast dish here. Staff are very friendly and accommodating and the setup is cute, quirky and ideally located on the ever classy Chiltern Street.

Yv5dPSbNHqPlA9pEXp9BvA.text: So - finally the Monocle Café has opened on Chiltern Street, completing a streak of considered branding and well-dressed staff that fully traverses Marylebone, and includes the magazine's offices (Midori House), a shop (George Street), a concession in the Hyatt on Portman Square, and now at long last, the café. For those of us that work in the area, this is welcome relief from Baker Street's chains and Marylebone High Street's lovely but pricey offerings (cf. Providores, La Fromagerie et al).The coffee is sourced from Redchurch Street-Kiwi outfit Allpress, with input on the pastries and baked goods from Lanka's Masayuki Hara and the London outpost of Stockholm's Fabrique bakery. A very strong line-up, then. Although not fully-operational menu-wise (... yet), the macchiato and espresso served was solid - if not quite perfectly pulled by the smart barista - but the macaron I was served on a second visit was La Durée-esque in its moist, flaky goodness. Other offerings, including Japanese chocolate bars ('Crunky'!), rollcake laden with fresh fruit and cream and lovely-looking cinnamon buns were available. In any case, once they've put their full breakfast/lunch (and brunch on weekends) menus in place then this review can be updated and be possibly more than a slightly-informative waste of time.The space itself is light, sleek and very, very 'Monocle'; brushed wood and clean lines lend the café the requisite Japano-Nordic feel, with seating outside underneath the awning complemented by a more sedate area at the back of the café with Monocle 24 - the brand's radio station - on constant loop and comfortable minimalist furniture to lounge in and kill your afternoon or chat away to your coffee companion.The lack of significant footfall will likely not detract from this being another very successful Monocle operation - the place is awash with Monocle-ites already, and with hotelier André Balazs opening what is looking to be a very swish - and likely very ££££ - boutique joint smack-bang opposite later on in 2013, flying trade is assured for the future. In short, go whilst the place is still half-empty and enjoy your Allpress espresso and matcha rollcake whilst being seated is still a realistic proposition.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Promotional shot of the cafe frontage

lj0bT1Rrv_z-dfvM39QhYg.text: This is a quirky cafe that does decent coffee with a japanese inspired lunch menu. Also a bit of  gift shop selling interesting things like hand made chocolates and nick nacks.Nice ambiance,  relaxing downstairs area to sit and enjoy. The food is nice but portions are small, after lunch I had to buy more food as I left hungry!

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Japanese breakfast (served all day)

T7ev9YIILKoYGlLk82GytQ.text: It was a destination. On a ridiculously rainy day. But as a stateside observer - one who is completely sucked into the Monocle ecosystem - I have long wanted to experience it. So I made my way over to it to realize I wasn't the only one with the same idea. If you don't know, the Monocle Cafe is petite. A small front room where you order, a small back room with some seating and a small downstairs with a few seats. That's about it. So having it high on my agenda of stops to make I had to make do. I ended up sitting by a small window on a stool perhaps designed for Prince George or someone of that size - which if you can imagine a man who is 6'3" sitting in is sort of hysterical on its own merits. Regardless, I enjoyed my flat white, the Guardian and the soon-to-be-gone Independent as the rain sloshed down around me - happy to have a seat at all as others came and realized they'd not be sitting at all.

rxAa2O0keQc6Sly21fF3Aw.text: Nice atmosphere and grilled cheese sandwich was so good. Must visit place for Monocle fan!

W8A27djcIKcDisrQ1oFALQ.text: Now this place deserves the adjective word, "cozy". Exhibit one is the toilet. They have the high-tech Japanese toilet that is ready to welcome you with heated seat, music, and variety of automatic flush features. You would wish to stay in their toilet longer if they had more than one. I tried one of them in Japan so I was very happy to find them here. I know it's not coffee-related review but a truly decent and dazzling toilet can make your visit special. Exhibit two is the interior. The place is not that big with only a couple side bars and stools and four tables for two people downstairs. But I liked the semi-private room on the first floor that has a comfortable sofa enough to fit 4 persons, a TV, and coffee tables. Most of the furnitures are very modern, simple, natural and space-savings, similar to what I've seen at Muji, the Japanese retail shop. Monocle magazines are everywhere for you to grab and read since this is the spinoff. In terms of food, monocle has a diverse selection of food from German breakfast to Japanese udon that can suit to whatever cravings you may have. Their small selection of pastries looked all enticing. I enjoyed the green tea cupcake and cinnamon roll accompanied by a hot mocha. The Bircher muesli and selection is toasts looked also very tempting and I have already made plans to visit this place again and try more food. Price is a bit above average. A regular cup of mocha is £3.50 and the cupcake is £3.50. They don't have wi-fi and that's why I didn't see anyone working on a laptop.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Inside monocle

-txkvnaiCUFDPVnI_2yP9w.text: Very very good coffee . Sandwiches and pastries delicious ! The room at the back is cosy with sofas ! Nice modern interior.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Midory Salad

9LoYeVk30HzVr_GoMW_G4w.text: Food was alright, ordered a flat white which tasted like cappuccino. Nice decor but quite a letdown to be honest

3XSb_drDCZYlgy_Kgv61Gw.text: Good coffee, small place and yummy morning pastries as the Cardamom puffed roll.

VhZMl4cUtNUNiE6wAATL6w.text: No wifi, no stars.I am sorry but here in London wifi available is compulsory, dpecially if it is announced.Good coffee and good service and atmosphere.

pnJEbPeVMP7rfaYSKR-VXw.text: Love this cozy little spot! their flat white is pretty stellar and probably one of the best I've had here. Can't wait to head back to try their lunch menu!

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Flat white

E9tqyJFErJQB2cBfq7639g.text: Everything is beautifully done. Lovely ambiance, outstanding lemonade and iced tea. Each beverage comes with a small square of chocolate. I am excited to return!

MJudI5vfXqlce6w0bm_kgA.text: Monocle Cafe is a chic, minimalist cafe in Marylebone from the creators of the same-named magazine and travel guide series. On offer is very good coffee at high prices, as well as light international fare.My boyfriend and I got Scandinavian and Japanese breakfast sets, respectively, and while neither blew us away they were competently done and a nice change of pace from the rich British food we ate all trip. Very simple and traditional.Service is lackluster, and though coffee was speedy, food is not exactly fast. Be sure to check out the additional seating in the back room and the cozy downstairs, and flip through their slim and design-centric city guides.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Scandinavian breakfast
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Coffee
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Japanese breakfast

imyjc6GlMb7XeEhzYl6r2A.text: There are many excellent third wave cafes in London, a few could be considered the finest anywhere. Monocle Cafe is an insult to third wave cafes everywhere. First, the "food" couldn't have been drier or more unappealing if it were a feminist's vagina. I won't go into details because I'd vomit at the trauma. The decor must've been inspired by a fast food sushi restaurant at a Scandinavian airport (its namesake publication has fetishes for both).  The pictures just don't do its sterility justice. A few minutes there will reduce your sperm count and cause you to miss a few menstruation cycles because your eggs will rot. Some cafes are sexy, Monocle Cafe is the antidote to Viagra. The employees are joyless and bewildered why you'd pay to be there. The other patrons are silently crying about what went wrong in their lives. Now then you'll their eyes begging for answers in desperately concealed misery. As for the coffee, well, you're not coming for that. You're there because you're a hermaphrodite in search of a pronoun. But it's terrible. A stain on the third wave coffee movement it pretends to be part of. Oh, please don't bring dogs or any other living innocence there. Not even they could protect you from such high exposures of pretension.

i6AvrpXtZ7TsAypDnXhmrg.text: One of my fave cafes in London, always welcoming and obviously great coffee too. I highly recommend the cortado, wonderfully accompanied by a choc mint. They serve food but have not samples as of yet. Love the back room which has sofas and a real living room feel as it is separate to the main area.

dOkZxRX1d5idVf4gZ6O2Iw.text: Great coffee spot with tasty coffee (reasonably priced considering the area) and very good service.You can also get complimentary mint flavored water.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom

NzCm1sGuFRAS9bjqxJ0OcQ.text: Coffee is great. Love it. Great ambiance interior & exterior. Highly recommend. If you can, avoid the food (at least the toasts). It's not great, very basic and lack of flavor. Avocado is super skimp, hardly much put on the toast- almost like decoration for color. The pictures of the menu at the till are deceiving.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Americano
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Avocado toast & Smoked salmon (substituted from Halloumi cheese)

K9hifHiF3BBpN65kcXh5LA.text: Absolutely love the coffee here. If I'm anywhere close to this part of town, I'll take a 10 minute walk to be able to pick up a coffee from the Monocle Cafe.Thanks to Dan for introducing me to this gem of a place.They have a good sized food menu too, but so far I've only stopped here for the coffee (hot and iced).There are a couple of tables out front on the pavement and since this road area low traffic volumes, it's a great place to sit in good weather.There are some comfy tables indoors too. It's a small space, but sufficient. Plus they have a tiny bar space opposite the serving counter.The staff are always super friendly and helpful and I always leave with a smile on my face.They have recently started a loyalty card where every 6th coffee is free.

R9vwR95Op9SJOWVECO6NBQ.text: We came here early on a Sunday morning and it was quiet and comfortable. I wish we could find places like that in San Francisco. Any decent place has crazy queues starting early in the morning. Anyway, I mainly loved the atmosphere, and the attention they paid to all the little details. The tea was really nice, huge pieces of ginger and fresh mint leaves, really warming and comforting. The cinnamon roll was quite nice as well but I think it's from another bakery, Fabrique perhaps. I would not get the avocado toast again because I personally do not enjoy spelt bread. I've had better. But I did hear that the katsu sandwich here is great, so try that!

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Avocado toast + halloumi
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Mint and ginger tea and a cinnamon swirl
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Such a cute facade

U2zVotfBUfFob-q4tmLeXg.text: Go downstairs where it is cozy and warm but don't arrive hungry. The avocado & halloumi sandwich was probably the tiniest, overpriced portion I've ever had. My friend had the grilled cheese, which was a bit more substantial but v messy. Must try Japanese breakfast next time!

ldGEQ3FUatII3JFAmfXDIA.text: We just stumbled upon this lovely coffee shop - what a great surprise! It is from the London guys who publish Monocle magazine, so a lot of stuff inside is themed accordingly, including playing their own radio in the background! The place is tiny when looking from the outside, but has extra seating downstairs. They also sell all sorts of packages with your coffee - walk a bit past the counter and you will see a sign for magazine + coffee, or coffee + tote or Christmas bundles including a guide book to any of their 15 destinations. Inside I also noticed quite a large menu for food - sandwiches, salads and a few other bites - which I would not think they would serve looking just from the outside. Too bad we already ate! And coffee? Was simply delicious, very milky and sweet :) And each cup comes with a small chocolate

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. A good selection of travel guides
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Christmas packages and magazines to go with your coffee
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. The sandwich/salad menu

3VUf7fhWOLmLCQgalUbS4A.text: Adorable cafe in Marylebone with Japanese-inspired dishes such as the Japanese breakfast with egg, miso soup, nigiri rice ball peppered with sesame seeds. There are also a selection of sammies, salads, soups, and other small nibbles such as matcha cakes and croissants. Every drink is served on a wooden tray and garnished with a tiny square of wrapped chocolate, a nice little touch. The downstairs seating space has to be the most impressive. It's very comfortable with a lengthy padded bench with tables suitable for studying or working. It does get quite hot downstairs in the afternoon, but offset it with a cold drink. They also recently started offering happy hour drinks around 1730. Staff are very attentive to customers and the space, so it is always very tidy. Green tea leaves a bit to be desired, the flavor profile is slightly off, so perhaps, sticking with the espresso-based drinks or black teas are a better option.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Downstairs space
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Green tea.

40ZXng2y0SNGYJYNSGF_Lw.text: So happy that I stopped into Monocle today on my way to Oxford Street! Advertised as a Japanese café that also serves Scandinavian breakfasts/pastries (...?), it's essentially just an airy, light space with an equally light yet filling menu. Everything about it is aesthetically pleasing - from the staff, whose shirts match the black and white striped awning outside, to the kitschy wooden plating - and it's a place that clearly takes both its coffee and its customers seriously.I was in the mood for a mocha this morning, and I'm super happy I tried one instead of my usual latte - it was very lightly sweet and had just the right hint of chocolate. I also tried the bircher muesli and, because I couldn't help myself, a chocolate chip cookie. Both were excellent, and I was definitely full after my meal.There is no wifi, which I was a bit worried about at first, but it gave me a great space to catch up on non-line work. I'm mentally bookmarking this as a place to come back to when I want to catch up with friends and put my digital life on hold for a bit.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Bircher muesli, mocha, and a cookie.

4qt0HJVyxKSpobBJnHsG2w.text: This place is lovely pocket sized Japanese inspired coffee shop where people give a damn about what they're doing.  Service was excellent. Design is beautiful (lovely Japanese touches).  A pure lemon juice lemonade was bracingly citrus.  An overly bitter macchiato at least came with 2 chocolates and some sugar.   The downstairs area has lovely smell of a Japanese bakery and a clean (of course!) little restroom with one of the toilets that does everything short of wiping your bottom for you.  Would loved to have tried a pastry but it was just before lunch. The plates looked delicious too.

JtavfB1561HHeQTUDqVI9A.text: Best cup of coffee near Baker Street. And let me tell you, Baker Street pours a crap lot of shit coffee, ok? Pret, Costa, Paul, Starbucks, Eat, Pret, Pure, Pret, Pret, Pret, Pret -- that's about the bar for Baker Street. If you're looking for an "indie" spot to grab your jolt, The Monocle Cafe will hit you where it counts. I'm not much for the whole "brand" or "lifestyle" of "Monocle" (cool if you are though) but they serve very good coffee and that is all I needed them for in this lifetime. The flat white, double espresso and iced americano x 20 powered me through many an afternoon. Anytime someone queried at the office "where can I actually get good coffee?" they were immediately sent here without hesitation with a warning on the price tag. Yes, it's overpriced. The coffee is great but it is expensive. £4 for an iced americano!? It is mostly water chappies! Oh well, clearly I sacrificed the coin to get the goods. Just be prepared for the sticker shock on some of the items. *not worker bee friendly (no wifi) -- not encouraged. *a few outside tables will allow you to people watch the who's who of London trotting in and out of Chiltern Firehouse. *there is more seating downstairs. *small Japanese cafe menu on offer (I've never tried) If you are reading this, you need coffee (good coffee) in the sea of dreaded chain coffeeland, here's your solve. You're welcome. Buzzzzzz.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Flat white

tBbusIaaVev8aAfsryWhIA.text: I went on a Saturday and was quite busy and difficult to find a seat. But in general, I enjoyed the cafe's ambience. The small room on the ground floor with couches where you sit with strangers was also quite fun. I tried the iced matcha latte, and loved how it wasn't sweet! Friends also say the (Japanese) food here is good too!

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. The avocado open sandwich. Looks small but quite filling!
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Ice green latte on the table at the ground floor room. See the other customers' bottles behind? Lol

0Y1A7eKPcdqpPouuw7Heyg.text: My husband and I were craving for a traditional Japanese breakfast and we were not disappointed by Monocle's breakfast (REAL miso soup, tofu, pickles, omelette and sesame onigiri). The location is super cosy and quiet,and the food was delicious. A real taste of Japan in London for 8£.The shop is quite small so seated places are limited, but if you go there on a week morning, the place is pretty empty (we got the back room with sofa and armchair for ourselves).

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Japanese breakfast

rCLjMSvzIrWLWBTm2x-gYw.text: Small cosy cafe in Marylebone area. Not in the high street, thus you will have to do a small search to find it. There is some extra seating downstairs. Excellent quality of coffee and of course you are in the source of one of the most hister magazines; The Monocle.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom

QXTnczuB7mm9CJ8kq9G8TA.text: Coffee- delicious & good, check. Ambience- bustling & quaint, check. Pastries- different & delicious, check. Basically covered everything I love & look for in a good coffee shop!!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom

LruHoU0F67cGufuQD9tZuw.text: How beautiful is this cafe! It's like living a day in a monocle magazine.The place is a mix of Japanese contemporary architecture and modern beech wood benches. The staff even got into the whole look and feel of the place. Coffee is pretty good, tea is even better and you can get matcha lattes here: yum.If you are into pastries go no further than the cinnamon scrolls. They are zesty, cardamom, sticky amazingness. The Swedish and the Japanese breakfasts are beautiful and light, but substantial making them a nice healthy start to the day. Biggest highlight of all: the heated toilet seat. Wow.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Even the coffee is beautiful
Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Japanese breakfast

dKqiNYT-H3pDQP3UzZsPTQ.text: Tucked away opposite on the Chiltern Firehouse, off of Baker street, this place is a real gem. It's what you'd want a quiet cafe to be--secluded, with friendly staff, lovely food, and baked goods. The best thing on the menu, undoubtedly, is the cardamom bun--a lesser known cousin of the now famous cinnamon bun. It was so good that I got one, took a bite when I left the shop, and then went right back in to get another one because my wife and I knew that our love wasn't strong enough to withstand sharing this piece of heaven.They have some unusual flavors in macaroons. My favorite would definitely be the black sesame and matcha.They have cakes from Lanka which I intend to go back for--especially the matcha variety. Expect me again soon, Monocle.

photos.caption: Photo of The Monocle Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Cinnamon and cardamom buns
